title: Histopathology-centered Computational Evolution of Spatial Omics: Integration, Mapping, and Foundation Models
summary: This paper provides a systematic survey of the computational evolution of spatial omics (SO) from a histopathology-centered perspective, organizing existing methods into three paradigms: integration, mapping, and foundation models. It analyzes how the role of H&E images, crucial for morphological assessment, evolves across these paradigms from spatial context to predictive backbone in response to practical constraints. The review further outlines actionable modeling directions and persistent challenges in the field, serving as a roadmap for developing SO computational frameworks.

title: Using Non-Linear Programming Solvers to Generate Hypothalamus-Pituitary Curves for Patients With Hypothyroidism
summary: This paper advocates for a more comprehensive approach to managing primary hypothyroidism by utilizing both Thyrotropin (TSH) and free Thyroxine (FT4) values, instead of TSH alone. It introduces Hypothalamus-Pituitary (HP) curves, generated via two novel non-linear programming solver methods, as a tool to determine patient-specific optimal thyroid hormone set points. These methods aim to enable physicians to develop personalized thyroid replacement strategies, with their efficacy tested against existing methods using literature and patient datasets.

title: DT-ICU: Towards Explainable Digital Twins for ICU Patient Monitoring via Multi-Modal and Multi-Task Iterative Inference
summary: DT-ICU is a novel multimodal digital twin framework designed for continuous risk estimation and patient monitoring in intensive care units (ICU). It integrates dynamic clinical time series with static patient data in a unified multitask architecture, providing accurate, temporally robust, and interpretable predictions that update throughout a patient's ICU stay. The framework consistently outperforms established baselines on the MIMIC-IV dataset, offering early and explainable insights into patient risk.

title: A Framework for Feature Discovery in Intracranial Pressure Monitoring Data Using Neural Network Attention
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework utilizing neural network attention to analyze intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring data, focusing on interpretability. A convolutional neural network was trained on ICP cardiac cycles from 60 patients to classify body positions, with extracted attention maps highlighting physiologically relevant regions within the waveform. The framework aims to deepen the understanding of ICP waveform characteristics, potentially leading to improved diagnostic capabilities.

title: Predictive Analytics for Dementia: Machine Learning on Healthcare Data
summary: This study developed and evaluated machine learning models for enhancing dementia prediction using patient health data, employing supervised learning algorithms and advanced data handling techniques. The research achieved a notable 98% testing accuracy with the Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) model, demonstrating its potential for early identification. It also highlighted the importance of model interpretability and identified the APOE-epsilon4 allele and chronic conditions like diabetes as key risk factors.

title: Neural Architecture for Fast and Reliable Coagulation Assessment in Clinical Settings: Leveraging Thromboelastography
summary: In an ideal medical environment, real-time coagulation monitoring can enable early detection and prompt remediation of risks. However, traditional Thromboelastography (TEG), a widely employed diagnostic modality, can only provide such outputs after nearly 1 hour of measurement. The delay might lead ...

title: Covariance-Driven Regression Trees: Reducing Overfitting in CART
summary: This paper introduces Covariance-Driven Regression Trees (CovRT) as a novel approach to mitigate overfitting in decision trees like CART, particularly in deep trees or with small sample sizes. By using a covariance-driven splitting criterion instead of empirical risk minimization, CovRT achieves more balanced and stable splits and identifies covariates with true signals more effectively. The method demonstrates superior prediction accuracy compared to CART in both theoretical proofs and empirical validations, enhancing model robustness and interpretability.

title: Critical Shortfall in NIH Support for Medical Physics Research
summary: This report analyzes changes in NIH funding for medical physics research between FY24 and FY25, revealing a significant shift in award composition despite stable overall funding for AAPM members. It identifies a 50% decline in competing awards, primarily due to an 80% collapse in new NCI R01 grants, raising critical concerns about the long-term stability and innovation capacity of the medical physics research pipeline.

title: Stable On-Policy Distillation through Adaptive Target Reformulation
summary: This paper introduces Veto, a novel objective-level reformulation for stable on-policy knowledge distillation (KD) that addresses the training instability and distributional gaps inherent in current methods. Veto constructs a geometric bridge in the logit space using an intermediate target distribution, effectively stabilizing optimization by adaptively suppressing harmful gradients and balancing output diversity with performance. Experiments show Veto consistently outperforms supervised fine-tuning and other on-policy baselines across various reasoning and generation tasks.

title: Towards Automated Diagnosis of Inherited Arrhythmias: Combined Arrhythmia Classification Using Lead-Aware Spatial Attention Networks
summary: This paper developed and validated a novel lead-aware deep learning framework, Lead-Aware Spatial Attention Networks (LASAN), for the automated multi-class classification of inherited arrhythmia syndromes (Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC), Long QT Syndrome (LQTS), and control) from ECGs. By optimally integrating LASAN with ECG foundation models via fine-tuning, the framework achieved state-of-the-art diagnostic performance (macro-AUROC 0.990) and demonstrated clinically plausible lead dependence, supporting its potential for automated ECG screening. It outperforms all existing published models for both binary and multi-class inherited arrhythmia classification.

title: MEDVISTAGYM: A Scalable Training Environment for Thinking with Medical Images via Tool-Integrated Reinforcement Learning
summary: Vision language models (VLMs) achieve strong performance on general image understanding but struggle to think with medical images, especially when performing multi-step reasoning through iterative visual interaction. Medical VLMs often rely on static visual embeddings and single-pass inference, prev...
